DOC.TEXT: Prices fell in light trading on Wall Street today, mimicking decines in the bond market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was off 2.35 to 2,709.04 as of 11 a.m. EST. Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of about 6 to 5, with 491 stocks rising, 617 declining and 526 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to a light 24.77 million shares in the first 90 minutes of trading following the three-day Christmas holiday weekend. Hildegarde Zagorski, a stock market analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said blue chip stocks were following the lead of bond prices, which declined in early trading today. The Treasury's 30-year bond was down | point, or $6.25 per $1,000 in face amount, while its yield rose to 7.93 from 7.88 late Friday. Analysts said some of the declines in bonds were attributable to investors adjusting their portfolios for the end of the year. However, there also was talk that sharply higher prices for heating oil, fruits and vegetables _ which could be in short supply due to the cold weather _ could accelerate inflation. Traders speculated that the Federal Reserve would be less likely to nudge interest rates lower if inflation is rising. The most-actively traded stock on the NYSE was Bank of New England, which rose } to 8\. AT&T was up \ to 45, IBM was off \ to 95[, and Sears, Roebuck was up [ to 36~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.15 to 191.80. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.37 to 370.47.
